results.headline: Rooting for One Player in Baseball Politics: Dad
results.summary_short: “Trouble With the Curve” is the anti-“Moneyball.” The old-time scouts from that earlier film, mocked for their superstitions about “intangibles” and “instincts,” get their revenge this time around.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trouble with the Curve

results.headline: Chefs With Stars in Their Eyes
results.summary_short: Chefs whose restaurants have earned the coveted three-star rating from Michelin Guides talk of their struggles, strategies and triumphs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Three Stars

results.headline: An Introvert Finds His Way Through Teenage Terrain
results.summary_short: “The Perks of Being a Wallflower,” about an introvert, touches on the themes often found in movies about teenagers.
results.display_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Perks of Being a Wallflower

results.headline: Old-Country Uncle Knows Best
results.summary_short: Vahik Pirhamzei plays the son of an old-country Armenian, and that son’s father, in the comedy “My Uncle Rafael.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Uncle Rafael

results.headline: A Hit in the End Zone, a Price for a Lifetime
results.summary_short: Steve James’s film “Head Games” examines the long-term consequences of some high-impact sports.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Head Games

results.headline: For Adults and Their Parents, a Difficult Crossroads
results.summary_short: “Fred Won’t Move Out” looks at the uncomfortable moment when adult children have to switch roles with their parents.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fred Won't Move Out

results.headline: Cops Who Tote Guns and Video Cameras
results.summary_short: David Ayer’s “End of Watch” has Jake Gyllenhaal and Michael Peña walking, and videotaping, a police beat among the gangs of South Los Angeles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of End of Watch

results.headline: Out Here, the Judge Is Also the Jury
results.summary_short: The action film “Dredd 3D,” based on the comic-book character, depicts a judgmental hero in a futuristic western dystopia.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dredd 3D

results.headline: A Hapless Musician Can’t Quiet His Inner Child
results.summary_short: In Ryan O’Nan’s “Brooklyn Brothers Beat the Best,” a hapless musician joins with a kindred spirit, and the two hit the road.
results.display_title: The Brooklyn Brothers Beat the Best

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Brooklyn Brothers Beat the Best

results.headline: A Career in Movies, but Not Those at the Multiplex
results.summary_short: “About Cherry” follows a California teenager who falls into the pornographic film industry after she moves to San Francisco.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of About Cherry

results.headline: Down the Rabbit Hole of a Peruvian Prison
results.summary_short: An American surfer hanging out in Peru finds himself jailed on trumped-up charges in “186 Dollars to Freedom,” and refuses to play along with corrupt officials to get out.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 186 Dollars to Freedom

results.headline: Brief Lives, Violently Extinguished
results.summary_short: Wrenching footage of missile attacks and their civilian victims in Vibeke Lokkeberg’s film transcends the politics of the conflict that underlies the bloodshed.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tears of Gaza

results.headline: Rekindling the Spirit of the ’60s, Even for Those Who Can’t Remember
results.summary_short: The documentary “Radio Unnameable” pays tribute both to Bob Fass, an influential voice in broadcasting since the 1960s, and to the times whose ideals and follies he helped articulate.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Radio Unnameable

results.headline: Alice, Still Fighting to Save the World
results.summary_short: In the fifth installment of the “Resident Evil” series, the leading lady is stripped of her superpowers and reunited with characters who were killed in previous movies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Resident Evil: Retribution

results.headline: Seeking Justice for Mom and Dad
results.summary_short: A boy who witnessed the killing of his parents studies martial arts and embarks on a mission in “Bangkok Revenge.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bangkok Revenge

results.headline: Second Thoughts on Marriage
results.summary_short: In “The Trouble With the Truth,” John Shea and Lea Thompson are a divorced couple, meeting when their daughter becomes engaged and looking back at their romance.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Trouble With The Truth

results.headline: A Little R&R for a Hit Man
results.summary_short: In “Snowman’s Land,” Jürgen Rissmann plays a two-bit hit man who, in need of a break, takes what seems like an easy job, protecting a twisted mobster’s wife in a mountain getaway.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Snowman's Land

results.headline: Food Artistry, Served Family Style
results.summary_short: Step Up to the Plate” looks at Michel and Sébastien Bras, renowned father-and-son chefs, as their restaurant and family undergo a changing of the guard.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Step Up to the Plate

results.headline: There Will Be Megalomania
results.summary_short: Philip Seymour Hoffman and Joaquin Phoenix star in Paul Thomas Anderson’s imposing, confounding and altogether amazing new film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Master

results.headline: High Flier, Poised for Steep Descent
results.summary_short: In Nicholas Jarecki’s “Arbitrage” Richard Gere plays a hedge-fund magnate whose glittering, rarefied world may be coming undone.
